Award.AwardTitle: Hydrodynamics of Liquid Crystals and Extremum Problems for Eigenvalues
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is for a deep theoretical study on a class of complex fluids including both the liquid crystals which have been widely used in display devices and charged biological fluids which are extremely important in modern medicine and life sciences. Of particular interests are their intriguing and complex dynamical phenomena as well as formations of patterns and singularities. The modeling, analysis and simulations involved in understanding these complex fluids are theoretically very important and challenging. It needs new ideas and methods, and hence it would advance our knowledge which would be applicable to many other scientific problems as well.

More specifically, the proposal consists of two parts. The first part is to study partial differential equations that describe the hydrodynamics of liquid crystals and related complex fluid models. The main focus of this part of the research will be to study global existence of suitable weak solutions of liquid crystal flows in the Ericksen-Leslie theory; the global existence of solutions of Oldroyd B-model of incompressible visco-elastic fluids; the inviscid incompressible magneto-hydrodynamic system and, in general, coupled nonlinear dynamics of fluids with other geometric objects. The second part is to study a large class of extremum problems of elliptic eigenvalues. Such problems also arise in optimal designs, pattern formations and other applications in material sciences and condense matter physics. The partial differential equations (PDE) that the PI plans to study involve nonlinear couplings between equations that describe transport, phase-field, mapping or geometric object's evolutions and that of Navier Stokes equations. They may be of both parabolic and hyperbolic nature and possess singularities or multiple scales. The variational problems for eigenvalues and eigenfunctions that linked with underlying domains are classical and fundamental. These are fascinating and challenging problems that require new ideas and methods, which could lead to new directions of research or programs in the analysis of PDE and calculus of variations. The proposed research activity is an important and integral part of the PI's training program of under-graduate, graduate, and post-doctoral students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project  is aimed to provide a rigorous mathematical theory to describe the hydrodynamics of liquid crystals and a more general class of complex fluids. It uses tolls from the geometric measure theory, calculus of variation and nonlinear partial differential equations. Particular issues of study include the global in time existence of certain solutions of liquid crystal flows as illustrated by the Ericksen-Leslie models;  the global existence of solutions of Oldroyd B-model of incompressible visco-elastic fluids and  the inviscid incompressible magneto-hydrodynamic system. The approach we employed would be useful in the studies of various coupled nonlinear dynamics of fluids with other geometric objects, fields and structures. The project is aimed also to investigate a large class of extreme problems eigenvalues of elliptic operators. Such problems arise often in optimal designs, pattern formations and other applications in material sciences as well as the condensed matter physics.

         The partial differential equations that the PI plans to study involve couplings between transport, phase-field, Fokker-Planck type, geometric evolutionary, and the Navier-Stokes equations. They may describe both dissipative and conservative dynamics, and they may possess sharp interfaces, singularities and multiple scales.  These are fascinating and challenging problems that require novel ideas and methods.

       This project is an important and integral part of PI's training program of undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral students. During the grant period, the PI had total five graduate students,  and four received their Ph.D degrees with themes of thesis related to this research project.   During the same period, the PI has organized (or co-organized) at least three international conferences on these topics and has given three sets of mini-courses at the symposiums and summer schools.  At the New York University, the PI also mentor in average five Math Major students per year.  During the grant period, the PI has published total 18 research articles.

       Among the research accomplishments, the PI and his collaborators provide a complete picture for evolutions of liquid crystals describing by the Ericksen-Leslie system in 2D; the finite time blow-ups in both 2D and 3D flows.  He collaborated with his student Jiajun Tong on the immersed boundaries in Stokes fluids which is an open problem for 45 years.The PI also worked with his postdoc  D.Kirenvtsov on the regularity of optimal shapes for extreme eigenvalue problems. It provides a theory for a new class of free boundary problems.
